00023 /* STP machine instance : bridge per VLAN: 17.17 */
00024 /* The Clause 17.13 points: "NOTE:The operation of the Bridge as a whole can 
00025  * be represented by the interaction between Bridge Ports specified,
00026  * and by parameters of the Bridge stored in "Port 0". This removes the
00027  * need for any "per Bridge" specification elements, and helps ensure
00028  * the minimum dependencies between Bridge Ports. This in turn supports
00029  * the development of implementations that scale well with increasing
00030  * numbers of Bridge Ports. This shift of focus to "per Port operation"
00031  * for the RSTP is supported by underlying technical changes from the
00032  * Spanning Tree Algorithm and Protocol (Clause 8):"
00033  * Newetheless, it seems to me, the behaviour of of the bridge, its variables
00034  * and functions are so distinct from Port, that I decided to design Bridge
00035  * instance. I called this object 'stpm' from STP machine. I'd like to see
00036  * another procedural model, more corresponding to this note on Clause 17.13 */
00037   
00038 #ifndef _STP_MACHINE_H__
00039 #define _STP_MACHINE_H__
00040 
00041 #include "port.h"
00042 #include "rolesel.h"
00043 
00044 #ifdef DELETME
00045 #define TxHoldCount          6 /* 17.16.6, 17.28.2(Table 17-5) */
00046 #else
00047 extern PORT_TIMER_T TxHoldCount;
00048 #endif
00049 class rstp_bridge;
00050 
00051 typedef enum {/* 17.12, 17.16.1 */
00052   FORCE_STP_COMPAT = 0,
00053   NORMAL_RSTP = 2
00054 } PROTOCOL_VERSION_T;
00055 
00056 typedef struct stpm_t {
00057   struct stpm_t*        next;
00058 
00059   struct port_t*        ports;
00060 
00061   /* The only "per bridge" state machine */
00062   STATE_MACH_T*         rolesel;   /* the Port Role Selection State machione: 17.22 */
00063   STATE_MACH_T*         machines;
00064 
00065   /* variables */
00066   PROTOCOL_VERSION_T    ForceVersion;   /* 17.12, 17.16.1 */
00067   BRIDGE_ID             BrId;           /* 17.17.2 */
00068   TIMEVALUES_T          BrTimes;        /* 17.17.4 */
00069   PORT_ID               rootPortId;     /* 17.17.5 */
00070   PRIO_VECTOR_T         rootPrio;       /* 17.17.6 */
00071   TIMEVALUES_T          rootTimes;      /* 17.17.7 */
00072   
00073   int                   vlan_id;        /* let's say: tag */
00074   char*                 name;           /* name of the VLAN, maily for debugging */
00075   UID_STP_MODE_T        admin_state;    /* STP_DISABLED or STP_ENABLED; type see in UiD */
00076 
00077   unsigned long         timeSince_Topo_Change; /* 14.8.1.1.3.b */
00078   unsigned long         Topo_Change_Count;     /* 14.8.1.1.3.c */
00079   unsigned char         Topo_Change;           /* 14.8.1.1.3.d */
00080 
00081   rstp_bridge *rstp; //leu: we keep a reference to our our bridge
00082   int                   debug;
00083 } STPM_T;
00084 
00085 /* Functions prototypes */
00086 
00087 void STP_stpm_one_second (STPM_T* param);
00088 STPM_T* STP_stpm_create (rstp_bridge *rstp, int vlan_id, char* name);
00089 int STP_stpm_enable (STPM_T* self, UID_STP_MODE_T admin_state);
00090 void STP_stpm_delete (STPM_T* self);
00091 int STP_stpm_start (STPM_T* self);
00092 void STP_stpm_stop (STPM_T* self);
00093 int STP_stpm_update (STPM_T* self);
00094 BRIDGE_ID *STP_compute_bridge_id (STPM_T* self);
00095 STPM_T *STP_stpm_get_the_list (rstp_bridge *rstp);
00096 void STP_stpm_update_after_bridge_management (STPM_T* self);
00097 int STP_stpm_check_bridge_priority (STPM_T* self);
00098 const char* STP_stpm_get_port_name_by_id (STPM_T* self, PORT_ID port_id);

00100 #endif /* _STP_MACHINE_H__ */
